awd_titl_txt: Leveraging the Hobby Eberly Telescope Dark Energy Experiment to Understand Lyman-alpha Emission, Galaxy Evolution, and Reionization
awd_abstract_narration:
Observations have shown that the physical conditions in distant galaxy interstellar media (ISM) are changing, but the physical cause remains unknown.  This project uses a soon-to-exist spectroscopic sample of galaxies showing Lyman alpha emission, which is an excellent probe of ISM geometry and kinematics, to measure the detailed physical properties of the ISM in these galaxies.  It will also measure the contribution of Lyman alpha emitting galaxies (LAEs) to star formation.  These results are critical to understanding the epoch of reionization.  The project integrates research with education by involving ten or more UT Austin students per year in research related to the source of the data, the Hobby Eberly Telescope Dark Energy Experiment (HETDEX).  It also impacts secondary school students nationwide through two residential teacher workshops at McDonald Observatory, and reaches millions by creating one StarDate Radio show each year.

The work will constrain the physical mechanisms which promote the escape of Lyman alpha emission from galaxies during the peak epoch of cosmic star formation.  Data for the first 300,000 spectroscopically confirmed LAEs from HETDEX will be combined with new extensive multi-wavelength imaging to i) measure the detailed evolution of the Lyman alpha luminosity function; ii) understand the physical properties which promote Lyman alpha escape; iii) measure the star-formation rate density contributed by LAEs; and iv) calculate the faint-end slope of the ultraviolet luminosity function for active galactic nuclei (AGN) to distinguish evolutionary trends and evaluate AGN contributions to reionization.  Stellar population modeling of detailed physical properties will measure the evolution of the global escape of Lyman alpha emission, and the physical causes behind this evolution, and provide key data to constrain theoretical models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant funded research using a new sample of galaxies from the Hobby Eberly Telescope Dark Energy Experiment (HETDEX).  This project, in-progress at McDonald Observatory in West Texas, has discovered a large sample of Lyman-alpha emitting galaxies (LAEs) in the distant universe, which are star-forming galaxies exceptionally bright in the Lyman alpha emission line.  We aimed to perform several investigations using these galaxies.  Some of the highlights are:

  • We contributed in a number of ways to the success of the HETDEX survey, including optimizing the data reduction, contributing to the emission line selection algorithms, and to a citizen science machine learning approach to clean the galaxy sample, ultimately leading to several public data releases.
  • We performed several investigations into the physical properties of LAEs, finding that in general they are younger, lower-mass, lower metallicity, and have more intense star-formation than galaxies with weaker Lyman alpha emission.  In a pilot project, we showed that we could use these properties to predict the Lyman-alpha emission strength from very distant galaxies, and are now in the process of making these predictions more robust with our full sample of ~20,000 LAEs.  By better being able to predict the emergent Lyman-alpha emission from galaxies, our results will significantly improve our ability to constrain the epoch of reionization, the time when the first stars ionized the bulk of the atoms in the universe.
  • We contributed to and led several projects on active galactic nuclei (AGNs) — accreting super-massive black holes in the early universe.  We found that the abundance of faint AGNs is much higher than previously thought, which could imply that AGNs play a role in contributing to reionization.
  • Our primary broader impact was the creation and expansion of a new undergraduate research program, called the “Galaxy Evolution Vertically Integrated Projects” program (GEVIP). This is an immersive, multi-year research program that involves sophomores through seniors, with returning students gaining valuable peer-mentoring experience bringing younger students up to speed. Following the induction of our Fall 2024 cohort, our team now includes 17 undergraduates working on data from HETDEX and JWST datasets. Two of our members have published papers on HETDEX projects (with several other students performing research with HETDEX data, presenting posters at AAS meetings).  In summer 2022 we also ran a teacher workshop funded by this grant, where ~a dozen secondary school teachers went to McDonald Observatory. In October 2021, we aired a StarDate radio program about components of this research, available here: https://stardate.org/radio/program/2021-10-28
